sections.heading: Learn Git
paragraphs: Git is a tool that helps you save and manage different versions of your files and code.
It allows you to work with others, keep track of changes, and undo mistakes.

sections.heading: Where to use Git?
paragraphs: Git works on your computer, but you also use it with online services like GitHub, GitLab, or Bitbucket to share your work with others. These are called remote repositories.
In this tutorial, you'll learn how to use Git for your own projects and how to connect with remote repositories online.

sections.heading: Learning by Examples
paragraphs: In this tutorial, we will show you Git commands including the input and the expected output.
For new users, using the terminal view can seem a bit complicated, but it gives you a good grasp of how Git works.
sections.code:
git --version
git version 2.30.2.windows.1
examples: Lines with $ in front of it is input. These are the commands you can copy and run in your terminal.

sections.heading: Tip for Beginners
paragraphs: Don't worry about making mistakes! When you use Git on your own computer, you can't really break anything important.
Experimenting is a great way to learn, and you can always undo or redo changes as you go.

sections.heading: What is Git?
paragraphs: Git is a popular version control system.
It was created by Linus Torvalds in 2005, and has been maintained by Junio Hamano since then.
It is used for tracking code changes, tracking who made changes, and coding collaboration.

sections.heading: Key Git Concepts
paragraphs: Repository: A folder where Git tracks your project and its history.
Clone: Make a copy of a remote repository on your computer.
Stage: Tell Git which changes you want to save next.
Commit: Save a snapshot of your staged changes.
Branch: Work on different versions or features at the same time.
Merge: Combine changes from different branches.
Pull: Get the latest changes from a remote repository.
Push: Send your changes to a remote repository.

sections.heading: Working with Git
paragraphs: Initialize Git on a folder to make it a Repository.
Git creates a hidden folder to keep track of changes.
When a file is changed, added or deleted, it is considered modified.
You select the modified files you want to Stage.
Staged files are Committed, creating a permanent snapshot.
Git allows you to see the full history and revert back to any previous commit.

sections.heading: Why Git?
paragraphs: Over 70% of developers use Git!
Developers can work together from anywhere in the world and see the full history of the project.
Developers can revert to earlier versions of a project.

sections.heading: What is GitHub?
paragraphs: Git is not the same as GitHub; GitHub makes tools that use Git.
GitHub is the largest host of source code in the world, and has been owned by Microsoft since 2018.

sections.heading: How to Install Git
paragraphs: You can download Git for free from git-scm.com.
Windows: Download and run the installer. Click 'Next' to accept recommended settings to install Git and Git Bash.
macOS: Use Homebrew (brew install git) or download the .dmg file.
Linux: Use your package manager (e.g., sudo apt-get install git on Ubuntu).

sections.heading: Git Bash
paragraphs: Git Bash is a terminal for Windows that lets you use Git commands and extra Unix commands like ls and pwd.
After installing, you can find it in your Start menu.
sections.code:
ls
Desktop Documents Downloads Pictures

sections.heading: Verifying Your Installation
paragraphs: Check that Git works by running the following command in your terminal:
sections.code:
git --version
git version 2.43.0.windows.1

sections.heading: Default Editor
paragraphs: During installation, you can pick a default text editor for writing commit messages.
sections.code:
git config --global core.editor "code --wait"
# Or for Notepad:
git config --global core.editor "notepad"

sections.heading: PATH Environment
paragraphs: Adding Git to your PATH is highly recommended so you can use Git commands in any terminal window.
If 'git is not recognized', you likely need to add Git's bin folder to your system's Environment Variables.

sections.heading: Line Endings
paragraphs: On Windows, it is usually best to select 'Checkout Windows-style, commit Unix-style line endings' to prevent cross-platform issues.

sections.heading: Configure Git
paragraphs: It is important to let Git know who you are so that your name and email can be attached to your commits.
Configuring Git is safe; you can change these settings at any time, and they only affect how your info appears in future commits.

sections.heading: User Name and Email
paragraphs: Set your username and email address globally so they are used for every repository on your computer.
sections.code:
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "you@example.com"

sections.heading: Viewing Your Configuration
paragraphs: You can list all your Git settings or check a specific value using the following commands:
sections.code:
# List all settings
git config --list

# View a specific setting
git config user.name

sections.heading: Configuration Levels
paragraphs: There are three levels of configuration with a specific order of precedence:
1. Local: Applied only to the current repository.
2. Global: Applied to the current user across all repositories.
3. System: Applied to all users on the computer.
sections.code:
# Example of setting a local config
git config --local user.name "Project Name"

sections.heading: Default Branch Name
paragraphs: You can set a custom default branch name (like 'main') for all new repositories you initialize.
sections.code: git config --global init.defaultBranch main

sections.heading: Get Started with Git
paragraphs: Once Git is installed and configured, you can begin using it by creating your first repository.
The process involves creating a project folder, navigating to it, and initializing Git.

sections.heading: Creating a Project Folder
paragraphs: Start by creating a new directory and moving into it using the terminal.
sections.code:
mkdir myproject
cd myproject

sections.heading: Initialize Git
paragraphs: Once you are inside the correct folder, initialize Git to start tracking changes.
sections.code:
git init
# Output: Initialized empty Git repository in /path/to/myproject/.git/

sections.heading: What is a Repository?
paragraphs: A Git repository is a folder that Git tracks for changes, storing all project history and versions.

sections.heading: What Happens When You Run git init?
paragraphs: Git creates a hidden folder called .git inside your project. This folder stores all the tracking information and history.
sections.code:
# Show hidden folders (Linux/macOS)
ls -a
# .  ..  .git

sections.heading: What is a New File?
paragraphs: A new file is a file that you have created or copied into your project folder, but haven't told Git to watch yet.
The key steps involve creating the file, listing it with 'ls', and checking its status with 'git status'.

sections.heading: Create a New File
paragraphs: Add a file to your project folder using a text editor. For this example, we will save a simple HTML file as index.html.
sections.code:
Hello world!

This is the first file in my new Git Repo.

sections.heading: Check File Status
paragraphs: Use 'ls' to list the files in your directory and 'git status' to see if Git is tracking them.
If a file is listed under 'Untracked files', it means Git sees the file but is not yet watching it for changes.
sections.code:
ls
# index.html

git status
# On branch master
# No commits yet
# Untracked files:
#   index.html

sections.heading: Tracked vs. Untracked Files
paragraphs: Untracked: Files in your folder that Git is not yet watching.
Tracked: Files that Git is watching for changes. To make a file tracked, you must add it to the staging area.

sections.heading: What is the Staging Environment?
paragraphs: The staging environment (or staging area) acts as a waiting room for your changes.
It allows you to specify exactly which files you want to include in your next commit, giving you full control over your project history.

sections.heading: Staging Files with git add
paragraphs: To add a specific file to the staging area, use the 'git add' command followed by the filename.
You can stage all changes (new, modified, and deleted files) at once using 'git add --all' or 'git add -A'.
sections.code:
# Stage a single file
git add index.html

# Stage all changes
git add --all

sections.heading: Check Staged Files
paragraphs: Use 'git status' to see which files are currently in the staging area and ready to be committed.
sections.code:
git status
# On branch master
# Changes to be committed:
#   new file: index.html

sections.heading: How to Unstage a File
paragraphs: If you accidentally stage a file, you can remove it from the staging area without deleting the file itself.
The primary command for this is 'git restore --staged <file>', though 'git reset HEAD <file>' can also be used.
sections.code: git restore --staged index.html

sections.heading: What is a Commit?
paragraphs: A commit is like a save point in your project. It records a snapshot of your files at a certain time, with a message describing what changed.
You can always go back to a previous commit if you need to.
sections.code:
git commit -m "message" # Commit staged changes
git commit -a -m "message" # Commit all tracked changes (skip staging)
git log # See commit history

sections.heading: Commit with a Message (-m)
paragraphs: To save your staged changes, use the -m flag followed by a clear message so you and others can understand what changed.
sections.code: git commit -m "First release of Hello World!"

sections.heading: Commit All Changes Without Staging (-a)
paragraphs: You can skip the staging step for already tracked files with the -a flag. This commits modified and deleted files, but does not work for new/untracked files.
Warning: Skipping the staging step can make you include unwanted changes. Use with care.
sections.code: git commit -a -m "Quick update to README"

sections.heading: Commit Message Best Practices
paragraphs: Keep the first line short (50 characters or less) and use the imperative mood (e.g., 'Add feature' not 'Added feature').
Leave a blank line after the summary and describe why the change was made, not just what changed.

sections.heading: Troubleshooting and Viewing History
paragraphs: If you make a mistake, use 'git commit --amend' to fix the last message or add forgotten files.
To view your history, use 'git log'. For a shorter view, use 'git log --oneline'.
sections.code:
git log --oneline
# 09f4acd Updated index.html with a new line
# 221ec6e First release of Hello World!

sections.heading: What is a Tag?
paragraphs: A tag in Git acts as a label or bookmark for a specific commit in your project history.
They are most commonly used to mark important points like releases (e.g., v1.0) or major milestones.

sections.heading: Annotated vs. Lightweight Tags
paragraphs: Annotated Tag: These store the author's name, date, and a message. They are recommended for official releases and public sharing.
Lightweight Tag: These are simple names for a commit that do not store extra information, functioning much like a bookmark.
sections.code:
# Create a lightweight tag
git tag v1.0

# Create an annotated tag
git tag -a v1.0 -m "Version 1.0 release"

sections.heading: Tagging Specific Commits and Viewing Tags
paragraphs: You can tag an older commit by providing its unique commit hash.
Use 'git tag' to see a list of all existing tags, or 'git show' to see the specific details of a tag and the commit it points to.
sections.code:
# Tag a specific commit
git tag v1.1 1a2b3c4d

# List all tags
git tag

# Show tag details
git show v1.0

sections.heading: Pushing and Deleting Tags
paragraphs: By default, tags stay on your local computer. You must explicitly push them to a remote repository for others to see them.
Note that a standard 'git push' command does not include your tags.
sections.code:
# Push a single tag
git push origin v1.0

# Push all tags at once
git push --tags

# Delete a tag locally
git tag -d v1.0

# Delete a tag from the remote
git push origin --delete tag v1.0

sections.heading: What is Git Stash?
paragraphs: Git stash allows you to temporarily save your uncommitted changes so you can return to a clean working directory without making a messy commit.
This is useful for quickly switching branches to fix urgent bugs or handle emergencies.

sections.heading: Stashing Your Changes
paragraphs: Use 'git stash' to save tracked files. To include new, untracked files, use the -u flag.
You can also add a message to your stash to help you remember what you were working on.
sections.code:
# Basic stash
git stash

# Stash with a message
git stash push -m "WIP: homepage redesign"

# Include untracked files
git stash -u

sections.heading: Managing the Stash Stack
paragraphs: Each stash is saved on a stack. You can list all stashes to see their IDs (e.g., stash@{0}) and messages.
You can view a summary of changes in the latest stash using the show command.
sections.code:
# List all stashes
git stash list

# Show latest stash details
git stash show

sections.heading: Restoring and Deleting Stashes
paragraphs: Use 'apply' to restore changes while keeping the stash in the list, or 'pop' to restore changes and remove the stash from the stack simultaneously.
If you no longer need a stash, you can drop a specific one or clear the entire list.
sections.code:
# Restore latest and keep in list
git stash apply

# Restore latest and remove from list
git stash pop

# Delete a specific stash
git stash drop stash@{0}

# Delete all stashes (Permanent!)
git stash clear

sections.heading: Branching from a Stash
paragraphs: If your stashed work should become its own feature, you can create a new branch and apply the stash to it immediately.
sections.code: git stash branch new-feature stash@{0}

sections.heading: What is Git History?
paragraphs: Git keeps a detailed record of every change made to your project.
You can use history commands to see what changed, when, and who made the change, which is vital for tracking progress and finding bugs.

sections.heading: Viewing the Commit Log
paragraphs: The 'git log' command shows a detailed list of all commits, including the author, date, and message.
For a quicker overview, 'git log --oneline' displays each commit on a single line.
sections.code:
# Show full history
git log

# Show summary history
git log --oneline

sections.heading: Comparing Changes with Git Diff
paragraphs: Use 'git diff' to see changes in your working directory that haven't been staged yet.
Use 'git diff --staged' to see what is ready to be committed compared to the last snapshot.
sections.code:
# See unstaged changes
git diff

# See staged changes
git diff --staged

sections.heading: Advanced History Filtering
paragraphs: You can filter the log by author, time frame, or even view a text-based graph of your branches.
sections.code:
# Filter by author
git log --author="Alice"

# Show commits from the last 2 weeks
git log --since="2 weeks ago"

# Show branch and merge graph
git log --graph --oneline

sections.heading: Showing Commit Details
paragraphs: To see the specific changes and metadata of a single commit, use 'git show' followed by the commit hash.
sections.code: git show 09f4acd

sections.heading: Why and When to Use Git Help?
paragraphs: Git has many commands and options. If you forget how a command works or want to learn about its options, you can use Git's built-in help.
This is the fastest way to get answers without leaving your terminal.

sections.heading: Key Commands for Getting Help
paragraphs: Use 'git help <command>' or 'git <command> --help' to see the full manual page for a specific command.
Use 'git <command> -h' to see a quick summary of options directly in your terminal.
Use 'git help --all' to list every Git command available on your system.
Use 'git help -g' to list guides and concept topics for deeper learning.
sections.code:
# Full manual for commit
git help commit

# Quick summary for add
git add -h

sections.heading: Navigating the Help Viewer
paragraphs: While viewing manual pages, use the arrow keys or Space to scroll, and press 'q' to quit at any time.
To search for a specific word, type '/' followed by your search term and press Enter.

sections.heading: Guides and Concepts
paragraphs: The 'git help -g' command is excellent for learning about advanced concepts such as attributes, glossary terms, and revisions.
sections.code: git help -g

sections.heading: What is a Git Branch?
paragraphs: A branch in Git acts as a separate workspace or 'parallel universe' where you can try new ideas without affecting the main project.
Branches allow you to develop new features, fix bugs, or experiment without interfering with the stable code on the main branch.

sections.heading: Creating and Listing Branches
paragraphs: Use 'git branch' to create a new branch or to list all branches in your repository.
An asterisk (*) next to a branch name indicates which branch you are currently working on.
sections.code:
# Create a new branch
git branch hello-world-images

# List all branches
git branch

sections.heading: Switching Between Branches
paragraphs: The 'checkout' command moves you from your current branch to the specified one.
You can also use the -b flag with checkout to create a new branch and switch to it immediately.
sections.code:
# Switch to an existing branch
git checkout hello-world-images

# Create and switch to a new branch in one step
git checkout -b emergency-fix

sections.heading: Working with Branches
paragraphs: When you switch branches, Git updates your working directory to match the snapshot of that specific branch.
Changes made and committed in one branch do not appear in other branches until they are merged.
sections.code:
# After switching to a new branch, stage and commit changes
git add --all
git commit -m "Added image to Hello World"

sections.heading: Deleting a Branch
paragraphs: Once work is finished and merged, you can delete the branch to keep your repository clean.
If a branch is not merged, Git will prevent deletion unless you use the force delete flag (-D).
sections.code:
# Delete a merged branch
git branch -d hello-world-images

# Force delete an unmerged branch
git branch -D branch-name

sections.heading: What is Merging in Git?
paragraphs: Merging in Git means combining the changes from one branch into another.
This is how you bring your work together after working separately on different features or bug fixes.

sections.heading: Merging Branches (git merge)
paragraphs: To combine changes, first switch to the branch you want to merge into (often main or master), then run the merge command with the branch name you want to combine in.
If no new commits were made on the base branch, Git performs a 'Fast-forward' merge by simply moving the branch pointer forward.
sections.code:
# Switch to the target branch
git checkout master

# Merge the feature branch
git merge emergency-fix

sections.heading: Advanced Merge Options
paragraphs: You can use specific flags to control how history is preserved during a merge.
--no-ff: Always creates a merge commit, even if a fast-forward is possible.
--squash: Combines all changes from the merged branch into a single new commit.
--abort: Cancels a merge in progress if you run into trouble.
sections.code:
git merge --no-ff feature-branch
git merge --squash feature-branch
git merge --abort

sections.heading: What is a Merge Conflict?
paragraphs: A merge conflict happens when changes in two branches touch the same part of a file and Git doesn't know which version to keep.
Git will mark the conflict in your file using markers like <<<<<<< HEAD and >>>>>>>.

sections.heading: How to Resolve a Merge Conflict
paragraphs: 1. Open the conflicted file and decide which version of the code to keep.
2. Remove the conflict markers and save the file.
3. Stage the resolved file with 'git add' and complete the merge with 'git commit'.
sections.code:
# After editing the file to resolve conflicts:
git add index.html
git commit -m "merged with hello-world-images after fixing conflicts"

sections.heading: Understanding the Git Workflow
paragraphs: Git uses a distributed workflow that allows you to work on your code, stage changes, and commit them to your local repository before sharing with others.
Understanding this workflow is essential for effective version control.

sections.heading: The Three Areas of Git
paragraphs: Working Directory: Where you make changes to your files.
Staging Area (Index): Where you prepare changes before committing.
Repository: Where your committed history is stored.

sections.heading: Basic Workflow Commands
paragraphs: Stage your changes using 'git add' to move them from the working directory to the staging area.
Save those changes to your local repository with 'git commit'.
Share your commits with a remote repository (like GitHub) using 'git push'.
sections.code:
# Stage a specific file
git add index.html

# Stage all changes
git add .

# Commit with a message
git commit -m "Describe your changes"

# Share with others
git push

sections.heading: Checking Status and Undoing Changes
paragraphs: Use 'git status' to see which files are currently staged, unstaged, or untracked.
If you make a mistake, you can use 'git restore' to undo changes in your working directory or 'git commit --amend' to fix your last commit.
sections.code:
# Check current status
git status

# Unstage a file
git restore --staged index.html

# Undo last commit (keep changes in working directory)
git reset HEAD~

sections.heading: Summary of Git Best Practices
paragraphs: Adopting good Git habits makes it easier for your team and your future self to understand and build on your work.
Key practices include committing often, writing clear messages, and using branches to keep your project stable.

sections.heading: Commit Often and Clearly
paragraphs: Make small, frequent commits to capture progress, which makes it easier to track changes and find bugs.
Use descriptive messages in the imperative mood (e.g., 'Add login validation') that explain why a change was made.
sections.code:
git add .
git commit -m "Fix bug in user login validation"

sections.heading: Maintain Stability with Branches
paragraphs: Create separate branches for features, fixes, and experiments to avoid affecting the main codebase.
Name your branches clearly, such as feature/login-form or bugfix/user-auth.
sections.code: git checkout -b feature/login-form

sections.heading: Collaborate Safely
paragraphs: Always pull the latest changes before you push to avoid conflicts and ensure your local branch is up-to-date.
Review your work using 'git status' and 'git diff' before committing to catch mistakes early.
sections.code:
git pull origin main
git push origin main

sections.heading: Repository Management
paragraphs: Keep repositories small by avoiding large files or unnecessary dependencies; use Git LFS for heavy assets like videos.
Use a .gitignore file to exclude build artifacts, logs, or secrets from being tracked.
Tag releases (e.g., v1.0) to mark important versions and make rollbacks easier.
sections.code:
# Example .gitignore
node_modules/
*.log
.env

# Tagging a release
git tag v1.0

sections.heading: Git Terms and Concepts
paragraphs: This glossary provides a reference for common Git terms used throughout the tutorial.
Refer to these definitions whenever you encounter unfamiliar terminology while working with version control.

sections.heading: Core Definitions
paragraphs: Repository (Repo): The database where your project's history is stored.
Index (Staging Area): Where changes are prepared and organized before they are committed.
Commit: A permanent snapshot of your changes in the repository.
HEAD: A reference to the current commit your working directory is based on, usually the latest commit on your current branch.

sections.heading: Branching and Merging
paragraphs: Branch: A parallel version of your repository used to develop features independently.
Merge: Combining changes from different branches into one.
Conflict: Occurs when Git cannot automatically merge changes, requiring manual resolution.
Checkout: The command used to switch between different branches or commits.

sections.heading: Remote Collaboration
paragraphs: Remote: A version of your repository hosted on the internet or a network.
Clone: Creating a local copy of a remote repository on your computer.
Push: Uploading your local commits to a remote repository.
Pull: Fetching and merging changes from a remote repository into your local one.
Origin: The default name assigned to your main remote repository.
Upstream: The default remote branch that your local branch tracks.

sections.heading: Advanced Utilities
paragraphs: Stash: Temporarily saving uncommitted changes to return to a clean state.
Tag: Marking a specific commit as important, typically for software releases.
Fetch: Downloading changes from a remote without automatically merging them.
Rebase: Moving or combining a sequence of commits to a new base commit.

sections.heading: Get Started with GitHub
paragraphs: GitHub is a web-based platform used for version control and collaboration, allowing you to host remote repositories online.
It enables you to back up your code and work with others effectively.

sections.heading: 1. Sign Up for GitHub
paragraphs: Go to GitHub and create a free account. It is recommended to use the same email address that you use for your local Git configuration.

sections.heading: 2. Create a Repository
paragraphs: Once signed in, click the 'New' button to start a new project.
Fill in your repository details, such as the name and description, and choose whether it should be Public or Private before clicking 'Create repository'.

sections.heading: 3. What is a Remote Repository?
paragraphs: A remote repository is a version of your project hosted on the internet rather than just on your local computer.
Connecting to a remote repository allows for secure collaboration and off-site backup of your project history.

sections.heading: What is SSH?
paragraphs: SSH (Secure Shell) is a protocol used to connect securely to remote services like Git repositories.
It utilizes a pair of public and private keys to ensure that only authorized users can access the code.

sections.heading: How SSH Keys Work
paragraphs: SSH keys function in pairs: a public key acts as a lock that you share with servers like GitHub, and a private key acts as your personal key kept safe on your computer.
Only the person with the private key can access what has been secured by the public key.

sections.heading: Generating a New SSH Key Pair
paragraphs: To create a new key pair, use the ssh-keygen command in your terminal.
It is recommended to set a passphrase for extra security when prompted.
sections.code: ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -C "your@email.com"

sections.heading: Adding Key to the SSH Agent
paragraphs: After generating the key, you must enable the SSH agent and add your private key so Git can use it for authentication.
sections.code:
eval $(ssh-agent -s)
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa

sections.heading: Copying Your Public Key
paragraphs: To complete the setup, copy your public key to your clipboard and add it to your GitHub account settings.
sections.code:
# macOS
pbcopy < ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

# Windows (Git Bash)
clip < ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

# Linux
cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

sections.heading: Testing and Troubleshooting
paragraphs: You can check which keys are currently loaded or test your connection to GitHub.
If you see 'Permission denied,' verify that your public key is in your Git host and your private key is loaded in the agent.
sections.code:
# List loaded keys
ssh-add -l

# Test GitHub connection
ssh -T git@github.com

sections.heading: Copy Your Public SSH Key
paragraphs: Before adding the key to GitHub, you must copy your public key to your clipboard using the appropriate command for your operating system.
It is important to complete this step before attempting to push, pull, or clone via SSH.
sections.code:
# Windows (Git Bash)
clip < ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

# macOS
pbcopy < ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

# Linux
cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

sections.heading: Add the Key to GitHub
paragraphs: 1. Log in to GitHub, click your profile icon in the top right, and select 'Settings'.
2. In the sidebar, select 'SSH and GPG keys' and then click the 'New SSH key' button.
3. Provide a descriptive title for your key, paste your public key into the 'Key' field, and click 'Add SSH Key'.
You may be required to confirm the action with your password or two-factor authentication.

sections.heading: Verify the Key
paragraphs: Once added, you should see your new SSH key listed in your GitHub account settings.
The next step is to test your connection and set your GitHub remote origin using SSH.

sections.heading: Set GitHub Remote Origin
paragraphs: After adding your SSH key to GitHub, you can securely connect your local repository to your remote GitHub repository using SSH.

sections.heading: Test Your SSH Connection
paragraphs: Before setting the remote, verify that your SSH connection to GitHub is working correctly.
If you see a message containing your GitHub username, you have successfully authenticated.
sections.code:
ssh -T git@github.com
# Hi your-username! You've successfully authenticated!

sections.heading: Get Your Repository's SSH Address
paragraphs: Navigate to your repository on GitHub, click the 'Code' button, and ensure 'SSH' is selected.
Copy the provided URL, which should start with 'git@github.com:'.

sections.heading: Add or Update the Remote Origin
paragraphs: Use 'git remote add' if you are connecting the repository for the first time.
If you already have a remote set up (such as through HTTPS) and want to switch to SSH, use 'git remote set-url'.
sections.code:
# Add remote for the first time
git remote add origin git@github.com:your-username/your-repo.git

# Update an existing remote to SSH
git remote set-url origin git@github.com:your-username/your-repo.git

sections.heading: Editing Code Directly in GitHub
paragraphs: GitHub provides a built-in web editor that allows you to modify code and documentation directly from your browser.
This is highly efficient for performing quick fixes, updating README files, or correcting minor typos without the need to clone the repository to your local machine.

sections.heading: The Editing Process
paragraphs: To begin, navigate to the file you wish to modify (such as index.html or README.md) and click the pencil icon located in the file's header.
The editor provides a standard text interface where you can add, remove, or modify code lines.
Before finalizing, you can use the 'Preview changes' tab to see a 'diff' view, highlighting exactly what has been added or removed.

sections.heading: Committing and Branching Strategy
paragraphs: Every change made in the web editor must be accompanied by a commit message that describes the purpose of the update.
By default, GitHub suggests committing directly to the main or master branch.
However, for larger code changes, you should select 'Create a new branch for this commit' to keep the main branch stable.
Once you commit to a new branch, GitHub will prompt you to open a 'Pull Request' (PR) so your team can review the changes before they are merged.

sections.heading: Pulling Changes from a Remote
paragraphs: When collaborating on a project, it is essential that everyone stays up to date.
The 'pull' command is used to update your local repository with changes made on GitHub.
It is actually a combination of two distinct Git commands: 'fetch' and 'merge'.

sections.heading: Git Fetch
paragraphs: The 'git fetch' command downloads new data from the remote repository but does not modify your local working files.
This allows you to review what others have done before you commit to merging those changes into your code.
sections.code:
git fetch origin
# Downloads recent changes from the remote called origin

sections.heading: Reviewing Remote Changes
paragraphs: After fetching, you can check your status to see how many commits you are behind the remote branch.
You can use 'git log' or 'git diff' to inspect the specific changes made on the remote server before merging them.
sections.code:
# See if your branch is behind
git status

# View the log of the remote branch
git log origin/master

# See specific code differences
git diff origin/master

sections.heading: Git Merge and Git Pull
paragraphs: If you have already fetched the changes, you can use 'git merge' to combine the remote branch into your current local branch.
If you want to perform both actions in a single step, use 'git pull', which automatically fetches and then merges the remote changes.
sections.code:
# Merge already fetched changes
git merge origin/master

# Fetch and merge in one step
git pull origin

sections.heading: Pushing Changes to a Remote
paragraphs: Once you have committed your changes locally, the next step is to update the remote repository on GitHub.
Transferring these local changes to the remote server is done using the 'push' command.

sections.heading: Basic Push Command
paragraphs: The standard push command uploads your local commits from your current branch to the remote repository named 'origin'.
Note that you must have already finalized your changes using 'git commit' before you can push them.
sections.code: git push origin

sections.heading: Force Pushing
paragraphs: Sometimes a push is rejected if the remote history has diverged from your local history (for example, after a rebase).
You can use the --force flag to overwrite the remote history, but this should be used with extreme caution as it can delete work done by others.
A safer alternative is '--force-with-lease', which only pushes if no one else has updated the remote branch in the meantime.
sections.code:
# Force push (Dangerous)
git push --force origin feature-branch

# Safer force push
git push --force-with-lease origin feature-branch

sections.heading: Pushing Tags
paragraphs: By default, standard pushes do not include tags. You must push tags explicitly to make them visible on GitHub.
sections.code:
# Push a specific tag
git push origin v1.0

# Push all local tags
git push --tags

sections.heading: Troubleshooting Push Errors
paragraphs: Non-fast-forward error: This usually means someone else pushed changes to the same branch. Solve this by running 'git pull' to integrate those changes before pushing again.
Authentication failed: Ensure your SSH keys are correctly set up and added to your GitHub account.

sections.heading: Working with Branches on GitHub
paragraphs: GitHub provides a web interface to create, manage, and delete branches directly in your browser.
This allows you to organize your work into different features or fixes before merging them into the main project.

sections.heading: Creating and Switching Branches
paragraphs: To create a branch on GitHub, click the branch selector button (usually labeled 'main' or 'master'), type a new descriptive name, and select 'Create branch'.
You can switch between branches in the web interface using the same dropdown menu.
sections.code:
# Switch branches via command line
git switch branch-name

sections.heading: Editing and Committing in a Branch
paragraphs: Once a branch is active, any files you edit and commit will only change within that specific branch.
You can use the 'Preview changes' tab to review your edits before finalizing the commit with a descriptive message.

sections.heading: Deleting and Renaming Branches
paragraphs: Branches can be deleted through the GitHub 'Branches' page or via the terminal once they are no longer needed.
Some branches, like 'main', may be protected to prevent accidental deletion or unauthorized force-pushes.
sections.code:
# Delete a local branch
git branch -d branch-name

# Delete a remote branch on GitHub
git push origin --delete branch-name

# Rename a branch locally
git branch -m old-name new-name

sections.heading: Merging Branches
paragraphs: To merge a branch on GitHub, the standard practice is to open a 'Pull Request'. This allows for code review and automated testing before the branches are combined.
sections.code:
# Merge a branch locally
git merge branch-name

sections.heading: Synchronizing Remote Branches
paragraphs: If a new branch has been created on GitHub by a teammate or via the web interface, you need to update your local Git to recognize it.
Running 'git pull' on your main branch will fetch information about all new branches available in the remote repository.
sections.code: git pull

sections.heading: Viewing Remote Branches
paragraphs: By default, 'git branch' only shows your local branches. To see branches that exist on GitHub but not yet on your machine, use the '-a' flag to show all branches (local and remote).
You can also use 'git branch -r' to view only the remote branches.
sections.code:
# Show all local and remote branches
git branch -a

# Show only remote branches
git branch -r

sections.heading: Checking Out a Remote Branch
paragraphs: To start working on a branch that currently only exists on GitHub, use the 'checkout' command followed by the branch name.
Git will automatically create a local version of that branch and set it up to track the remote version.
sections.code:
git checkout html-skeleton
# Switched to a new branch 'html-skeleton'
# Branch 'html-skeleton' set up to track remote branch 'html-skeleton' from 'origin'.

sections.heading: Verifying the Local Branch
paragraphs: After checking out the branch, you can confirm it is active and up-to-date by running a quick branch and pull check.
sections.code:
# Confirm current active branch
git branch

# Ensure you have the latest code
git pull

sections.heading: Pushing a Local Branch to GitHub
paragraphs: When you create a new branch on your local computer, it does not automatically appear on GitHub. You must explicitly push the branch to the remote repository.
This allows you to share your specific feature or fix with the rest of your team.
sections.code:
# Create and switch to a new branch
git checkout -b update-readme

# After committing changes, push the branch
git push origin update-readme

sections.heading: Push and Set Upstream
paragraphs: If the branch doesn't exist on GitHub yet, you can use the '--set-upstream' (or -u) flag.
This links your local branch to the remote branch, so in the future, you can simply use 'git push' or 'git pull' without specifying the branch name.
sections.code: git push --set-upstream origin update-readme

sections.heading: Managing Remote Branches
paragraphs: You can also perform advanced actions like pushing all local branches at once or deleting a branch from the remote server.
sections.code:
# Push all local branches to GitHub
git push --all origin

# Remove a branch from GitHub
git push origin --delete update-readme

sections.heading: Force Push and Tags
paragraphs: A force push overwrites the branch on GitHub with your local changes. This is risky and should only be used when you are certain it won't delete a teammate's work.
To share release markers or milestones, remember to push your tags separately.
sections.code:
# Force push (Use with caution!)
git push --force origin update-readme

# Push all local tags
git push --tags
